section.title: Zebra Types
section.p: Zebra supports simple types (int, long, float, double, string, bytes), complex types (record, collection, map) and Booleans.

tr.td: character array (string) in Unicode UTF-8 format
An ordered set of fields. A field can be any Zebra type.
A set of key/value pairs. The key is type string; the value can be any Zebra type.

section.p: Zebra type names are chosen to be as “technology neutral” as possible and are in resemblance to native types in modern programming languages.

section.title: Store Schema Specification
section.p: The Zebra store schema is used to write or store Zebra columns and to specify column types. The schema supports data type compatibility and conversion between Zebra/Pig, Zebra/MapReduce, and Zebra/Streaming. (In a future release, the schema will also support type compatibility between Zebra/Pig-SQL and will guide the underlying serialization formats provided by Avro for projection, filtering, and so on. )
The basic format for the the store schema is shown here. The type name is optional; if not specified, the column defaults to type bytes.

section.title: Schemas for Simple Data Types
section.p: Simple data types include int, long, float, double, string, and bytes. The following syntax also applies to Booleans.

section.title: Syntax
section.p: field_alias[:type] [, field_alias[:type] …]

tr.td: The name assigned to the field column.

(Optional) The simple data type assigned to the field.
The alias and type are separated by a colon ( : ).
If the type is omitted, the field defaults to type bytes.
Multiple fields are separated by commas.

section.title: Storage Specification
section.p: The Zebra storage specification is used to specify column groups and the columns in those groups.

The storage specification describes the physical structure of a Zebra table where $PATH/tbl indicates the table_directory and column_group_name indicates the subdirectories within the table_directory. The STORE statement below indicates the following:
section.source: STORE A INTO '$PATH/mytable' USING org.apache.hadoop.zebra.pig.TableStorer('[a1, a2] AS A; [a3, a4, a5] AS B');

section.title: Specification
section.p: The basic format for the Zebra storage specification is shown here. For this specification, note that the straight brackets [ ] designate a column group and the curly brackets { } designate an optional syntax component.

section.title: Syntax
section.p:
[column_name {, column_name ...} ] {AS column_group_name} {COMPRESS BY compressor_name} {SERIALIZE BY serializer_name}
{; [column_name {, column_name ...} ] {AS column_group_name} {COMPRESS BY compressor_name} {SERIALIZE BY serializer_name} ... }

tr.td: Brackets designate a column group. Multiple column groups are separated by semi-colons.

Optional. The name of the column group. Column group names are unique within one table and are case sensitive: c1 and C1 are different. Column group names are used as the physical column group directory path names.
If specified, the AS clause must immediately follow the column group [ ].
If not specified, Zebra will assign unique default names for the table: CG0, CG1, CG2 ... (If CGx is specified by the programmer, then it cannot be used by Zebra.)

Optional. Valid values for compressor_name include gz (default) and lzo.
If not specified, gz is used.

Optional. Valid values for serializer_name include pig (default). (In a future release, Avro will be available.)
If not specified, pig is used.
The name of one or more columns that form the column group.

section.title: Examples
section.p: In this example, one column group is specified; the two statements are equivalent.
section.source:
STORE A INTO '$PATH' USING org.apache.hadoop.zebra.pig.TableStorer('[c1]');
STORE A INTO '$PATH' USING org.apache.hadoop.zebra.pig.TableStorer('[c1] AS CG0 COMPRESS BY gz SERIALIZE BY pig;');
section.p: In this example, two column groups are specified. The first column group, C1, has two columns. The second column group, C2, has three columns.
section.source: STORE A INTO '$PATH' USING org.apache.hadoop.zebra.pig.TableStorer('[a1, a2] AS C1; [a3, a4, a5] AS C2');
